. It was founded in 1895 by former Union Army drummer boy Philander H. Fitzgerald on behalf of Union Civil War veterans, leading to the nickname
. You'll see the Civil War history in the street signs: Union generals on the east, Confederates on the west, and at the Blue & Gray Museum. More importantly, though,
Fitzgerald is off I-75 at the intersection of US-129 and GA-107, an hour and a half drive south of

Wandering around town, keep an eye out for

or somewhere that looks an awful lot like a chicken, several of which were introduced for reasons well-masked by a Fitzgerald sense of humor. They have fled the boring old woods for the charming city center—look for them downtown. Today they are the city mascot, loved and unloved by a whimsically ambivalent populace.

value: content=This museum, in a historical railroad depot, is dedicated to the founding of the town and its Civil War past, as well as to veterans of later foreign wards from the town.
hours=Third weekend of March: F 7PM-10PM, Sa 6AM-6PM

content=March is the time to see Fitzgerald strut its stuff. There are a couple 5ks and fun runs, the Miss Wild Chicken pageants, live music, and—of course—the Fitzgerald Fire Department Wing Eating Contest (FFDWEC).
content=Right at the center of town next to the Grand Theatre (Central and Main) is this solid pizzeria, with a nice atmosphere, and a lot of high end coffees and craft beers (bottled).

content=Also right in the center of town is this local favorite restaurant. It's cafeteria buffet-style with very friendly owners—Nabila learned to cook in her native Egypt, but she serves some of the best Southern cookin' you'll find in the state.
content=The obvious place to stay in style when visiting Fitzgerald, this colonial mansion is on the National Historic Register, has modern amenities, and a good price. Also, the owner is the mayor!
The local area code is 229 and is not required for local calls.
and its Jail Museum are just a half hour drive west on GA-107.
